00001 
00002 /** 
00003  * @mainpage EagleEye - An Automated Test Pattern Generator
00004  * @version  0.2
00005  * @auth Kirtika Ruchandani, Kashyap Garimella
00006  * @date 3/2/2010
00007  *
00008  * This program has been developed as a part of the CS633 course at IIT Madras,
00009  * Digital Systems Testing and Testable Design. The aim is to take a verilog
00010  * description of a simple combinational circuit (supports all gates including
00011  * XOR and BUF, which are used in the ISCAS '89 benchmarks) and to output 
00012  * a set of test vectors which cover all the detectable faults in that circuit.
00013  *
00014  *
00015  * @note
00016  * 1. This code is under GIT version control.Please use the latest source from
00017  * http://github.com/rkirti/EagleEye . 
00018  * Comments,flames and suggestions are welcome either on the github
00019  * comments section or at kirtibr@gmail.com.
00020  * 
00021  * 2. You need to have a recent version of lex and yacc installed 
00022  * to be able to compile.
00023  */
00024 
00025 
00026 #include "circuit.h"
00027 #include "fault.h"
00028 #include "atpg.h"
00029 #include "lexer.h"
00030 
00031 
00032 using namespace std;
00033 
00034 
00035 /// A global circuit is used for now to facilitate easy interaction with the
00036 ///  parsing  module
00037 Circuit circuit;
00038 
00039 /// Declaring the debug files.
00040 ofstream MAIN_DFILE;
00041 extern ofstream ATPG_DFILE;
00042 
00043 
00044 /**
00045  * @brief
00046  *
00047  * Main Program - Takes care of the complete flow from calling the lexer to 
00048  * parse the verilog description, setting up the circuit structures to 
00049  * setting up the fault sets for the test and actually performing the
00050  * test and capturing the test vectors. Please check the main.debug
00051  * in the debug folder after running the code to get a concise picture of
00052  * the whole run.
00053  *
00054  * @param The main function takes in the name of the verilog file which has the circuit
00055  * description.
00056  *
00057  * @return Always returns a value of 0.
00058  */
00059 
00060 int main(int argc,char **argv)
00061 {
00062 
00063     if (argc != 2)
00064     {
00065         cout << "Usage: ./bin/atpg <benchmarkfile> " << endl;
00066         exit(0);
00067     }
00068 
00069     /// MAIN FUNCTION TASKS
00070 
00071     ///  Call the lexer to parse the verilog description and populate the circuit
00072     ///  data structure.
00073 
00074     if( !lexer(argc,argv) )
00075     {
00076         cout << ":(" << endl;
00077         exit(0);
00078     }
00079 
00080     /// Open all the files needed for writing debug info.
00081     Init_Debug();
00082 
00083     /// Levels are needed for evaluation.
00084     Levelize(circuit);
00085 
00086     /// Name the branch wires correctly.    
00087     Resolve_Branches(circuit);
00088 
00089 
00090     /// Write both possible faults for each wire in the fault file.
00091     Generate_Full_FaultSet();
00092 
00093     /// Create a test object to run ATPG
00094     ATPG curTest;
00095 
00096     /// Read the faults from a pre-specified file into the test object's data structure.
00097     Read_Faults_Into_FaultSet( "tests/faults.txt",circuit, curTest.faults); 
00098     Print_FaultSet(curTest.faults);
00099 
00100     /// Finally run ATPG on the fault set.
00101     curTest.tests =  curTest.PerformTest(circuit, curTest.faults);
00102     curTest.Print_Test_Set();
00103     return 0;
00104 
00105 }
